div.p: 1. VI. Friday

On going to the House this morning, I told my Coachman Thomas, if he should come for me this Evening, not to come till Ten O’Clock— There was a Resolution, two or three days ago, reported from the Committee of Commerce; calling upon the Secretary of War, to make report at the next Session of Congress, of a Survey of Lake Erie— As soon as it was before the House, Lake Huron was added to it by way of Amendment. Bronson then moved to add Lake Ontario— Others moved for Lakes Michigan and Superior— After some discussion upon each of these amendments, Whittlesey of Ohio, moved as a substitute a joint Resolution on authorising the President to cause surveys to be made of such parts of Lakes Ontario, Erie, St. Clair, Huron, Michigan and Champlain, with their Bays, rivers and Straits— Wise then moved to include the waters of Chesapeake Bay, and the Creeks adjacent thereto— After some resistance by Whittlesey, and a spice of sectional altercation, Whittlesey accepted Wise’s Amendment.— The Stanley moved to include Albemarle Pamlico and Core Sound, upon which Charles Shepard, proposed other Sounds in North Carolina and thus the Resolution went on swelling till it was ready to break down by its own weight, when with the hour of 11. came the special order of the day, and the Committee of the whole on the State of the Union, Howard in the Chair, upon the Indian Appropriation Bill— Turney resumed his Speech of bitter personalities against
against Bell, which he continued for nearly two hours; reading long extracts from old printed documents and Speeches of Bell, to convict him of inconsistency— Bell replied—using as he always does gentlemanly language, but in the tone which the most exasperated resentment assumes to express unmitigated contempt— He spoke of Turney as a man of whom he had scarcely known any thing—until he met him on the floor of the House—said his personal relations with him had been slight but not unfriendly— That Turney could have no possible motive for ill-will towards him; but that he had made himself the voluntary Scavenger of all the filth raked up by others. That the political associates for whom he acted (meaning Polk the Speaker, and Grundy the Senator from Tennessee) whether in or out of the House were men equally destitute of public principle, and of private worth— He had said all of this of them at home, in his own district, where he had dared them to meet him, and had exposed their falsehood and hypocrisy— That they never had dared to meet him, but had set Turney, to make this unprovoked attack upon him in the House—that Turney had thus become the voluntary instrument of the malice of others; the tool of tools.— At these words Turney who was sitting within arms reach of Bell, started up and with furious gesture looking him in the face,—cried it is false, it is false—upon which Bell struck him with his fist— Turney aimed a blow at Bell in return, and they were rushing at each other when the members adjoining separated them— Cries of Order, Speaker, Serjeant at arms, instantly arose— Polk the Speaker, darted up to the Chair, turned Howard out of it, and called upon the Serjeant at arms to keep order— The tumult then subsided of itself and the Speaker to justify himself for resuming the Chair, read from Jefferson’s Manual. p. 132. of the new Edition of the Rules, their Precedents as reported from the British House of Commons.— All was now quiet; but what was to be done with the dignity of the House— Howard, the extruded Chairman of the Committee of the whole, whose position seemed to me almost ludicrously aukward, thought himself obliged to apologize to the House, for what he had obviously no power to prevent— He said he had yesterday called once or twice Turney to order for wandering into personalities—that the incident this day was so sudden and instantaneous that there had not been time for the Chairman to interpose— A motion was made that the Chairman of the Committee of the whole House, should take the Chair again; but this was not comformable to the Precedents— Mercer was for resorting to his old expedient of requiring a pledge from the parties that they would pursue the quarrel no farther; but Wise remonstrated against this, and after a short discussion, Mercer’s motion was laid upon the table by the tellers 86 to 52— The House were on the point of going into Committee of the whole again when Pennybacker offered a Resolution requiring Bell and Turney to make apologies to the House for having violated its privileges, and offending its dignity.— Yell moved to lay this motion on the table, but Grant called for the yeas and nays, which were 21. to 155— When the call
call had proceeded about one third through the names, and it was apparent that there would be a very large majority against laying it on the table; Wise asked that it should be superseded, both the Gentlemen being ready to volunteer apologies; very much ashamed of themselves, and quite sufficiently punished already the call was however carried through— Then without waiting for the passing of the Resolution, Bell and Turney successively apologized, and disclaimed all intention of disrespect to the House; whereupon the Resolution was by general consent laid on the table; and the House went on motion into Committee again. Bell then resumed his speech of self vindication against the slaver of Turney, but as he kept himself within the rules of order his discourse was stale and flat, like a pot of small beer after a bumper of pure whiskey. He was followed by Underwood, and he by Halstead, who since his unlucky waterspout with Governor Lincoln about the Jet d’eau has been silent, but who now gave a dissertation equally dull and self conceited— This closed the debate— The question upon Bell’s amendment was taken by tellers and carried 77 to 70. to the great astonishment, and annoyance of Cambreleng who called for a new count, insisting that many of the members had mistaken Bell’s amendment for the one which he was to offer, by instruction from the Committee of Indian Affairs— An additional Appropriation for the ultimatum from the Secretary of War to the Cherokees— Anderson of Maine said he had mistaken the question and moved a reconsideration of the vote— Dromgoole raised a point of order, whether a reconsideration could be moved in Committee of the whole— The Chairman said it could. The Speaker was of the same opinion— Bell thought it could not, but moved the amendment proposed by the Indian Committee— Anderson withdrew his motion for reconsideration.— The amendment of the Indian Committee was adopted without a division, and the Committee of the whole on the Union rose and reported the Bill with the amendments— House adjourned.— It was pouring down floods of Rain— I took a Seat in a Hack with Sergeant, and Edward Davis, another member from Pennsylvania—drop’d them at their lodgings and came home— There was an evening party at Mrs Meade’s, to which Hull went, but Mary sent an excuse— There was some debating in the House, on the amendments reported by the Committee of the whole on the Union, to the Indian Bill, upon which Cambreleng urged for the passage to the third reading— The adjournment was carried by tellers 88 to 81.
2. V:30. Saturday.

Our Coachman, Thomas, as he was accounting to me this morning for purchases of provisions at market, was taken suddenly with a faint turn, which soon passed away; but left him so weak, that I thought it best for him to take some repose— Isaac Hull Adams volunteered and drove me in the Barouche to the Capitol. Mary and her daughter Fanny went with me— Hull took leave of me there, and went in this afternoon’s Cars, with his friend Campbell to Baltimore. Hull has been with us, from the 6th. of March, and is now going to his mother at Quincy. Campbell belongs to Albany, and is going thither. H.R.U.S. Cambreleng moved that the Indian hostility Bill with the amendments reported by the Committee of the whole on the state of the Union should be printed. Two Messages from the President were received— One of them with a Report from the Secretary of State in answer to the Resolution offered by me last Monday. He says that all the correspondence with Texas relating to the annexation has been already com-municated
-municated— That there has been no correspondence on the subject with any other Government, and that the proposition of annexation made by the Texas Government having been disposed of in the correspondence heretofore communicated has not been since deemed within the control of the United States— The question whether the application has been withdrawn, remains unanswered— The Message was referred to the Committee of Foreign Relations— There was a Report from the Secretary of War on the cost of allowances to be made to the Cherokees to be removed, for improvements, spoliations and etceteras to the amount of more than two Millions— Governor Lincoln obtained a suspension of the Rules to offer a Resolution to fix next Monday which he afterwards modified to Friday, to take up the Bill reported from the Committee on the Public Buildings, for removing the Walls of the Treasury building now half finished and for erecting a fire proof Patent-Office— Three hours, from ten to one, were at last yielded against long and captious opposition— I called for the reading of the memorial from the starving workmen, and it was read— This day had been fixed for the consideration of Bills reported from the Committee of Revolutionary Claims— Committee of the whole, Elmore in the Chair 26 Bills were reported without amendment, among which the Bill for the relief of the Heirs of Crocker Samson. 51 Bills were reported with amendments, principally striking out the allowance of interest reported by the standing Committee. Eleven Bills were reported with the enacting clause struck out, among which that for the relief of the heirs of Francis Cazeau and nineteen Bills were laid aside for further consideration— Among these was the Bill for granting seven years half pay to the widows or children of certain officers of the Continental line of the Revolutionary Army— There was a Bill authorising the issuing of Land warrants to the widows or children of certain revolutionary Officers, slain in Battle before the 24th. of Septr 1776.— I moved to amend by inserting, or who died in the Service, to take in the case of the heirs of Genl. John Thomas—but Underwood objected that this case had been provided for, by the seven years half-pay under the Resolution of Congress of 14. Octr. 1780. and brought me a Volume of Gales and Seaton’s Documents, containing a Report from Genl. Knox when Secy of War shewing that the 7 years half pay had been paid to the heirs of Genl. Thomas.— About 3. O’Clock some question was made on which it appeared there was no Quorum; and the Chairman, left the Chair and reported the fact.— Nothing had been done in Committee. An attempt was made to adjourn—which failed— A call of the House was ordered. Petrikin moved to adjourn assigning on the Journal the want of a Quorum as the reason; and publishing the names of the members present— I moved as an amendment to strike out the names of the members present, and publish the names of the absent— The Speaker said the motion was not in order— The call was pursued until a bare Quorum appeared—the Speaker left and the Chairman resumed the Chair— The Committee completed its business, reported the bills on which it had taken questions, and asked leave to sit again upon the rest, which was granted. The House adjourned at 5. O’Clock— Returning home I met the Carriage with My wife, Mary and her daughter Fanny— They landed me at our house and pursued their ride. Hull was gone in the Cars— A young French woman named Grandval came, as a preceptress
preceptress to the children— Speaking only French, it is hoped they will more easily learn the language.— Mary-Louisa is unwell, and seems to be in drooping health; never wholly recovered since she had the meazles.
3. V.30. Sunday

I took Mary and her daughter Fanny with me this morning to the Capitol, where in the Representative Hall, Harriet Livermore preached from Luke 23–34. “Then said Jesus, Father, forgive them, for they know not what they do”— A discourse on the absolute and unqualified forgiveness of injuries— Indirectly only against dwelling—not even indirectly against Slavery— Eleven years have passed away since I first heard her in the same Hall; more than six since I had heard her last— Age has in that time traced furrows on her brow.— She has no longer the charm of youth— The silver tones of her voice have become brassy, and she is labouring with one of these violent bilious coughs— She came to see me after the service, accompanied by Mr Cogswell of New-Hampshire, who she said lodged at the same house with her and made a voluntary offer to come with her— I reminded her that when I heard her at the Capitol in 1832 she had announced her intention of going to the western Indians. She said she had been there with the approbation of the Government, and the warm recommendation of President Jackson— But the Schermerhorns of that region, by which I understood the male missionaries had forced her away, and robbed her of all her property— She had stated her claim for restitution or indemnity to President Van Buren, who had graciously referred her to the Secretary of War— He was sick—but his chief Clerk had assured her that her claim would be faithfully enquired into, and this she had no doubt was the last she would hear of it— She said she had since been at Jerusalem, and had only three weeks since returned to the United States— She spoke with great kindness of the converted Jew missionary Joseph Wolff, who she said was the greatest man living and of whose prediction that the Millennium is to commence in 1846 she declared her entire belief— Tis rather too soon— There is a permanency in this woman’s monomania, which seems accountable only from the impulse of vanity; and the love of Fame— The religious Spirit easily allies itself to these Passions, and they, eagerly grasp the garb of religion.— The holy Spirit avails itself of these purposes to promote its own cause— When Harriet Livermore preaches in the Representative Hall of the United States the forgiveness of injuries—alas! how few converts, will she make! and yet? is there no blessing of God, for a word spoken in Season? Is there no avenue to improvement in the heart of man? There is— Harriet Livermore towards the close of her discourse, upon the absolute, unqualified and irremissible command of Jesus Christ to his disciples to
to practice the duty of mutual forgiveness, said there was no portion of mankind, upon whom that obligation was more imperiously binding than upon those who filled the Seats in that Hall— May some of those who heard her lay it to their hearts, and Harriet Livermore will have worthily fulfilled her destiny upon earth— Mrs Frye and Miss Johnston were here after morning worship at St. John’s church, but did not stay— I attended there after dinner. A stranger read the Evening service for Whitsunday and preached from Jeremiah 31.31. “Behold, the days come, saith the Lord, that I will make a new covenant with the house of Israel, and with the house of Judah: 32. Not according to the covenant that I made with their fathers, in the day that I took them by the hand, to bring them out of the land of Egypt; (—) 33. But this shall be the covenant that I will make with the House of Israel: After those days, saith the Lord, I will put my Law in their inward parts, and write it in their hearts; and will be their God, and they shall be my people.” The preacher had upon his countenance the traces of a thinking man, as well as of affliction— His discourse was very intelligent and yet too unwieldy for his grasp— He had many reflections not fully digested on the nature of Covenants and he intimated that the term was improper as expressive of any relation between God and man—because he said the general acceptation of the word covenant, implied something like equality between the parties— The word covenant therefore thus used was equivalent to commandment or Testament— It was the word used for both parts of the Bible—the old and the new Covenant, and meant the Sovereign will of God. All this is true— But Covenant is not mere will— Obedience to the Will of God is the universal Law of the Bible— But it is the obedience of a free Agent, and therein consists the peculiar nature of Man— Matter, obeys the will of God— The brute creation obeys the will of God— All submit to his controul— All fulfil his commands— With man only, he makes a covenant, and man only by the immortality of his nature acquires the faculty of contracting even with God— This principle requires developement, and is the key to the whole bible, and the whole duty of Man.
4. V. Monday

Attended the Committee of Manufactures at 9. Present Adams, Naylor, Slade, Tillinghast, Webster, who came in, and made a Quorum about 5 minutes before 10. Absent Biddle, Foster, Hunter and Vail. I was directed to report a Bill to refund to the Georgia Steamboat Company the duties paid by them upon iron for a Steam-boat, imported in the British ship Alcyone in 1836. I had drafted a Bill to remit the duties paid also upon the Steam Engine, and for a general importation free of duty of Steam-boat iron.— But to both these Naylor and Tillinghast objected, and the reduced Bill is accordingly to be reported. A man by the name of Caldwell, called me out of the Committee room, and had some complaint against the Postmaster General, and the Post-Office Committee, but I had
had not time to hear him; and promised to call at his own lodgings and see him to-morrow— H.R.U.S.— Petition day— At the motion of E. Whittlesey—sundry Bills from the Senate were twice read and referred to Committees— The presentation of Petitions took not more than two hours.— I presented one from Anna Swinerton, for a widow’s pension— I found it on my table, and know not whence it came.— I stated that I had received certain Resolutions of the Legislature of Massachusetts, adopted at their recent Session, relating to Slavery and the Slave trade in the District of Columbia, and in the Territories, which under ordinary circumstances, I should deem it my duty now to present— But it would be recollected by the House, that last week one of my Colleagues—W. C. Calhoun had presented to the House certain Resolutions of the same Legislature, of a kindred character, though not the same—they related to the admission into the Union any new State, with a Constitution tolerating the existence of Slavery within its borders— That the Speaker of the House, by a construction which I deemed erroneous of the Resolution of the 21st. of December last, had decided that those Resolutions, presented by my Colleague should be laid on the table without being read, printed, referred, or considered— That my Colleague on a subsequent day, had applied to the House for leave to withdraw those Resolutions; with the avowed purpose of making known to his constituents and mine the manner in which they had been treated by the House— That this leave had been granted, and that afterwards my Colleague had offered a Resolution, now pending for the future consideration of the House; declaring that the order of the 21st. of December 1837. shall not be construed to include the Resolutions of any State Legislature— That I should not now present the Resolutions of the Legislature of Massachusetts with which I was charged, but should reserve them, until by the action of the House upon the Resolution offered by my Colleague it should be ascertained, whether the Resolutions of the Legislature of my native Commonwealth would be treated by this House, with the respect to which they are entitled, or with contempt.— While I was making this Statement Campbell of South-Carolina first rose, and made a question of order— The Speaker said, that if I had Resolutions of the Legislature of Massachusetts to present——— I said I was stating to the House the reasons why I should not present them, and must therefore necessarily refer to the proceedings of the last week, and the Resolution offered by my Colleague.— There were two or three other faint calls to order before I finished, and the Speaker was apparently much inclined to arrest me; but did not venture to do so. I went through— Ingham of Connecticut, presented two sets of Resolutions of the Legislature of that State, one in favour of the claimants for indemnity for French Spoliations prior to 1800—the others strongly protesting against the Patton Gag— They were laid on the table and ordered to be printed— Cambreleng presented a Petition from coloured Citizens of New-York; complaining, of a regulation in the Island of Cuba, by which coloured mariners arriving there are imprisoned— There is precisely such a regulation at Charleston South-Carolina— Owens offered a Resolution, instructing the Committee of Manufactures to enquire into the expediency of a general act for
for the free admission of Steamboat iron, and of other special admissions and remissions— Cushing obtained a suspension of the rules, for a Resolution to distribute certain Books to members of this and former Congresses—and the Resolution passed through its three readings at once— After the Resolutions, Cambreleng called up the Indian hostility Bill— Sergeant asked him when he proposed to bring on the Sub-treasury— He said next week— After the pre-emption Bill— The whigs are now very fearful that the sub-treasury Bill will pass— A sufficient number of the Western Members being converted to it, by the pre-emption Bill— The Indian Bill was now taken up, and debated by Wise, Graham of North-Carolina, Biddle, Legare, Downing, and after a call by Cushman, for the Previous Question which failed, by Everett, Biddle and Downing again, Bell and M’Kay and Waddy Thompson, Bell’s amendment was rejected by yeas and nays 90 to 112— The amendment proposed from the Committee of Indians affairs was adopted by two votes, one of 189 to 15—the other of 174 to 20—and the Bill after another previous question and refusal of yeas and nays passed to be engrossed, and then passed by yeas and nays 143 to 37. Upwards of 20 members present did not vote on the passage of the Bill— Six Members of the Massachusetts Delegation voted against it. Briggs, Cushing and Hastings did not vote. Borden Parmenter and myself voted for the Bill— There was a sharp passage between Biddle, and the Delegate from Florida, Downing, who received a richly merited castigation till he turned pale with anger, but made no reply— The House adjourned after 7. and I rode home in heavy rain.

div.p: 5. V. Tuesday

This day and tomorrow had been some time since fixed for the consideration of Bills relating to the Territories— Whittlesey of Ohio proposed that before commencing upon them the Committees should be called for Reports— But the whole of the two days having been assigned to the Territories, Yell of Arkansas objected to taking up anything else. Several Reports from Committees were received and Bouldin, Chairman of the Committee on the District of Columbia, obtained the assignment of Monday the 11th. after the morning hour. He had proposed Tuesday the 12th. but Yell again interposed and said it should be a more distant day— So he proposed the day before.— I objected that Monday was the day for Petitions, and Bouldin modified his motion, to except the morning hour, and thus it was adopted— The Committee of the whole was discharged from the consideration of all the Bills relating to the Territories, which had been referred to them, and they were all referred to the Committee of the whole on the State of the Union— The House then went into Committee of the whole on the Union John Sergeant in the Chair— Bills to open land-offices in Wisconsin, West of the Mississippi, to create a surveyor general, to establish a new judicial district in Florida, to survey and ascertain the boundary lines between Wisconsin and Missouri, and between Wisconsin and Michigan, were laid aside to be reported after very short discussion upon one of them—the Bill to divide the Territory of Wisconsin, and establish the territory of Iowa, was the first that bred debate— Mason of Ohio, without declaring himself against it, moved to strike out the enacting clause, to elicit information; stating that allegations were abroad of numerous occupations of the public Lands by unlicensed interlopers
interlopers— Crary of Michigan briefly answered him— Mercer opposed the Bill, as unnecessary and inexpedient until the portion of Wisconsin East of the Mississippi shall be constituted as a State— Waddy Thompson with more candid disclosure of real purpose opposed the Bill on the avowed ground of maintaining the balance of power between the Slave-holding and non-slave-holding States. He said he would never consent, and hoped no Southern man would ever vote, for making new Territories, or admitting new States from the Northwest into the Union, so long as the Northern fanatics were pouring in floods of petitions, against the admission of that great and glorious people of Texas, which had applied for admission into our Union, as was desired most earnestly by a large portion of our own Country and for which proposals in this House had been made but not considered— Bronson complimented Thompson for his candour, remarked that the Northwestern territory was actually a parcel of our Union to the People of which we were under obligations of positive duty— He would not enter into the discussion about the annexation of Texas, but it was not now within the pale of the Union— Pope spoke in favour of the Bill, and said the present population of Wisconsin West of the Mississippi was much more numerous than that of Arkansas when gifted with a territorial Government— Bronson said the present population was about 30000 each side of the Mississippi— Thompson replied, insisting upon the claim of the people of the South to the annexation of Texas, to preserve the balance of power, especially in the Senate— Mercer, Everett, Jones of Wisconsin, Charles Shepard and White of Kentucky took part in the debate, but no answer was given to Thompson— I rose once and addressed the chairman, but he did not hear me— The motion to strike out the enacting clause was rejected without a division— Bond moved a reduction of the Salary of the Governor, which after some discussion was adopted— Then came a Bill granting Land to the Territory of Wisconsin to open a Canal—after some discussion laid over— An appropriation for a Law Library for the Councils and Courts in Florida—and an appropriation for a compilation of the Laws of Florida— The Committee reported all the Bills, excepting that for the grant of the land to open the Canal— The amendments were adopted in the House and the Bills, passed to the third reading and passed—except the Bill constituting the Territory of Ioway—which Thompson moved to lay on the table— The House adjourned about 5. without taking this question— I called at Mr Caldwell’s, and he told me, not very clearly his grievances against the Postmaster General, and the Post-Office Committee— Mr Briggs who is on that Committee came in while I was there; and I referred Caldwell to him for redress, promising my aid if there should be occasion— I had written out, what I said in the House yesterday, concerning the Resolutions of the Legislature of Massachusetts, upon Slavery and the Slave trade in the District of Columbia and the Territories— I left the paper with Mr Gales at the Intelligencer Office— Afterwards, recollecting that I had by mistake dated it Monday 28 May. I wrote a Note to Gales, or the foreman of the Office, to correct it in the publication— Sent it by William, but Gales was gone. He left the Note with his clerk.

div.p: 6. IV:15. Wednesday

Dark and heavily showery day. My wife, our grand child Mary Louisa, and myself are afflicted with severe and obstinate coughs, which have been epidemic this Season, and which return with every change of weather— That of my wife is distressing. H.R.U.S. Elisha Whittlesey succeeded this morning in his motion that the Committees should be called for Reports, and I reported from the Committee of Manufactures, the Bill for repayment to the Georgia Steamboat company, of the duties paid by them on the importation from Liverpool of iron for a Steamboat in 1836.— Fairfield gave notice that he would on Friday call up the Northeastern boundary Bill— The territorial Bills were again taken up— That for creating a surveyor General in Wisconsin, and that for ascertaining the Southern boundary of the Territory were passed— The Bill constituting the Territory of Ioway was largely debated— Downing, the delegate from Florida moved the Previous Question but it was not sustained. Bond had moved to reduce the Salary of the Governor proposed in the Bill at 2000 dollars as Governor, and 1500 dollars as Superintendent of Indian Affairs to 1500 as Governor, and 1000 as Indian Superintendent— The sums reported in the Bill were declared by the Chairman of the Committee, Bronson, to be the same established by Law, and now received by the Governor of Wisconsin. Bond called for the yeas and nays, and intending to vote against the reduction, I gave my reasons for the vote; and commented upon the spurious economy which vents itself in charges of extravagance and declamations against executive patronage, and contents itself practically with nibbling at the Salaries of subordinate Officers— I took the occasion while up of answering Waddy Thompson’s declaration that he would vote for no new Northern Territory, while Northern fanatics were pouring in Petitions against the annexation to this Union of the great and glorious Republic of Texas— I objected to the peculiar glory of Texas which consisted in having made of a Land of Freemen, and land of Slaves— I said we had too much of that sort of glory already—and was proceeding to illustrate by the atchievements of the late Philadelphia Mobs when the stunning cries of order emboldened the Speaker to order me to take my Seat— Thompson intreated that I might be allowed to proceed, insisting that I was strictly in order— But I had said as much as I wished to say then, and I did not appeal from the Speaker’s decision— I had some sparring with Mercer, about the size of the new Territory— It was finally found that Bond’s amendment put the Salary of the Governor of the Territory of Ioway at the same sum now allowed to the Governor of Wisconsin— The amendment was accepted and the Bill after further discussion passed by yeas and nays 113 to 51— Committee of the whole again on sundry territorial Bills, reported to the House and passed with some exceptions.— Adjourned about 5.— Mr Frye was here in the Evening— I received a Letter from Commodore James Biddle at Baltimore, informing me that my nephew Joseph Harrod Adams has this day passed a very good examination— Joyous news— Change of Bed chamber to my Study.
7. IV:30. Thursday

Mrs Adams is exceedingly ill, and coughed incessantly almost the whole Night through— She was cupp’d this day— Her voice entirely gone, with a severe stricture across the breast and a sharp stitch at the left side— My own existence is of course wretched. Yet I attended the Meeting of the Committee of Manufactures— Present Adams, Naylor, Slade, Tillinghast, Vail, Webster— Absent, Biddle, Foster, Hunter.— The Resolution offered by Owens on Monday instructing the Committee to enquire into the expediency of a general Law for the admission of Steam-boat iron duty free— Also of a special privilege to G. B Lamar to import two iron-boats and to remit the bonds of the Georgia Steam boat Company on another was debated— No conclusion— All the members present except myself incline against the general Law; and the special applications as they multiply are less favourably viewed— Adjourned to Thursday.— H.R.U.S.— Whittlesey’s transformation of a Resolution reported by the Committee of Commerce directing the Secretary of War to send to the House at the next Session copies of Surveys in his Office of Lakes Erie and Michigan, into a joint Resolution authorising the President to have surveys made of Lakes Ontario, Erie, St. Clair, Huron, Michigan and Champlain Chesapeake Bay, Albemarle, Pamlico and Core Sounds, and maps and charts of such Surveys to be made; without one cent of appropriation came up, and ran through to the question upon its third reading without one word of opposition— I then rose and observed that approving exceedingly the object of the Resolution, I thought it should be in the form of a Bill, with an Appropriation— That the Chesapeake Bay, and the North-Carolina Sounds were superfluous, being already included in the general survey of the Coast, and as this measure would be a gigantic stride in the system of internal improvement, it would be well for the House to understand what they were about in passing this Resolution— Some of the Southern internal improvement haters were startled, but it was too late— Cushman, was in favour of the Resolution and moved the previous Question, insisting that the Resolution would not involve one cent of expense— Mallory called for the yeas and nays and they were refused— Haynes moved to recommit to the Committee of Commerce, to report a general survey— No!— A Resolution which if its import had been understood would have raised Months of debate, and then certainly rejected, was now driven through by the shrewdness of Elisha Whittlesey, and the dogged mortification at the anti-internal improvement men, at their own failure to detect the mine sprung upon them by this Resolution— The gravity of Whittlesey and the stolidity of Cushman in maintaining that it involved no expense were diverting. Mallory intimated that the Resolution was smuggled through the house, which was resented with great indignation by Whittlesey, who scourged the Southern men, for first lumbering his Resolution with Chesapeake Bay and North-Carolina Sounds, and
and then urging the weight of the Resolution to break it down— It was passed by the previous question, and without yeas and nays— Kilgore moved a suspension of the rules to offer a Resolution to suspend for two years the provisions in the acts of 14. April and 23. June 1836. which forbid the receipt by the Government the Bills of Banks which issue Bills under 5 dollars— On the yeas and nays the whole delegation from Massachusetts, except Phillips who did not vote, and Cushing and myself, who voted against the suspension, voted for it— The vote for the suspension was 96 to 91—not two thirds— The rule was of course not suspended; but there was an ascertained majority for the measure— Carter of Tennessee attempted to obtain a special order for the Bill to extend the pension system, but failed— Fairfield moved to go into Committee of the whole on the Union, upon the North-eastern boundary Bill: he was persuaded to modify his motion to go into the Committee Generally— This succeeded Craig of Virginia, was Chairman of the Committee. Fairfield and Garland of Louisiana, rose and addressed him simultaneously—but though Fairfield had moved to go into the Committee, and stated the object of his motion to take up the Boundary Bill, the Chairman gave the floor to Garland, who moved to take up the land pre-emption Bill, and it was taken up—and debated—various amendments offered until about 4 O’Clock when the Committee rose, with a prospect of much more future debate—adjourned about 5— I came home with a heavy heart— Evening visit from Mr Daveis, and long conversation with him on the North-eastern boundary— I told him the administration would not suffer the boundary Bill to pass and that they ought in candour to say so to the Maine delegation. I inferred it conclusively from the incidents of this morning in the House.
8. IV:15. Friday.

My wife had again a very bad night and is yet exceedingly ill, but with some abatement of the severest symptoms— Dr Thomas attends her, in the place of Dr Huntt, himself in the last Stage of a consumption, unable to continue his practice— H.R.U.S—three hours of this day, from 10 to 1. O’Clock had been fixed for the discussion of the Bill reported by the Committee on the public buildings, to take down the Walls of that now unfinished and apply the Stone for the construction of a fire proof Post-Office Edifice, and build another brick building for the Treasury Department— Committee of the whole on the state of the Union John Pope in the Chair— Naylor began the debate in favour of the Report, and was answered by George H. Keim a Pennsylvania German Democrat just supplying the place of the departed Muhlenberg— Keim looks at this object and all others through the smoky lens of party Politics, and stands by the wretched bungler in Architect Mills, because he was recommended by Mr Jefferson— Zadock Pratt, a member of the Committee, a full blooded Administration man, but a house builder himself, and an honest man, made a Speech of half an hour founded wholly upon facts, and such was its impression upon the Committee that if Governor Lincoln could have sacrificed his unparalleled eloquence to the success of the cause, the Committee would at that moment have risen and reported the bill and it would have run triumphantly through the House, before they would have had time to cool— But no—he saw the eager impatience of the House, but he could
could not forego the glory of conquering by his Speech, and promising to detain the Committee only a very few minutes, and had been about half an hour in full blast of a Speech without symptom of approaching to a conclusion when Pope the Chairman announced that the hour of one had arrived and the Committee must rise— There was an earnest wish in the Committee to close the discussion, but Pope insisted upon the Committee’s rising, and they did, and reported progress— Lincoln moved a suspension of the Rules to go into Committee again; which was done, with the same Chair-man— Lincoln abridged and finished his Speech— He called upon Cushing to testify to the bad construction of the Custom house at Newbury-Port, of which Mills was the Architect. Cushing testified that the walls of that building did like Desdemona seriously incline; not towards union, but to divorce, and that a great iron bar across the whole building had been found necessary to keep them in their bearings— Cushing was irresistibly facetious, and while up, gave his advice to take down the embryo Palace of the Treasury Department, and build a plain, brick fire-proof, republican work house for the Department in its place.— Then there was a desultory debate— Amendments proposed—a motion to strike out the enacting clause of the Bill 44 to 63 no quorum—then 59 to 66—rejected—sundry amendments adopted and reported with the Bill to the House— Sherrod Williams then moved to lay the Bill on the table and a call of the House— The call was pursued until 171. members answered to their names, and then by yeas and nays the Bill was laid on the table 89. to 82.— Bills at their third reading were then taken up, and sixty-three of them with two joint resolutions were passed— Among the Bills was that for the relief of the Heirs of Crocker Sampson— Sundry Bills from the Senate were twice read and referred to Committees— Henry Johnson moved an instruction to the Committee on the judiciary to enquire into the causes of the failure of the last U.S. Circuit Court in Louisiana, and the attempt of the District Judge to remove the Clerk of the Circuit Court without sufficient cause— And there was a Message from the President with claims from the Marshal of the Northern District of New-York for charges in suppressing frontier disturbances— The Message recommends a general Appropriation— Adjourned at 5. O’Clock— I walked home—the hottest day of the Season. I had called at the chamber of the Committee on Agriculture, and in the Library to see Dr Perrine, according to his request in a Note that I had received from him; he was not there, but afterwards sent me word that he would meet me, at a time which I fixed at half past nine to-morrow Morning in the chamber of the Committee of Agriculture. Mr Cushing introduced to me, behind the Bar Mr Sereno E. Dwight, who told me that Dr Sherwood of New-York was here, and having made a discovery of no less magnitude than a method of ascertaining at all times and in all places the Latitude and Longitude, by the mere variation of the magnetic needle, without any celestial observation; he wished to exhibit to me his demonstration of, and the operation of the machine invented by him— I agreed to meet him, with Mr Dwight, and Mr Cushing to morrow Morning at nine, in the chamber of the Committee of Manufactures— Evening visit from Mr Silsbee.
9. IV:30. Saturday

Second day of high Summer heat— My wife still confined to her bed, with burning heat, and a racking cough— Sleepless Nights in Succession— Dr Thomas in attendance twice a day— I could not reach the Capitol till 1/2 past 9. Made an apology to Dr Perrine, and engaged to meet him at the chamber of the Committee of Agriculture next Tuesday at 1/2 past 9— I met Dr Sherwood with Dr Sereno E. Dwight and Mr Cushing in the chamber of the Committee of Manufactures, and heard till 11. their exposition of the discovery which Dr Sherwood claims to have made, and of the machines invented by him for ascertaining the Latitude and Longitude of places by the variation of the magnetic needle.— I have not Science enough to understand it; but as the elements of his discoveries, he claims to have achieved what all preceding writers on magnetism had conceded to be impracticable—that is to magnetise an iron ring— He had with him two magnetised rings— He avers that the magnetic Poles of this Globe are upon the Arctic and Antarctic circles—and that the variations of the magnetic needle have a range East and West from the Poles of 23 degrees and 28 minutes— He reduces the Laws of Variation to fixed and unalterable rules, and makes the variation of the Needle and the Latitude and Longitude of any given spot on the globe mutual demonstrations of each other— There is great ingenuity in the invention of the instrument, but I comprehended very imperfectly its adaptation to the theory— Dr Sherwood wants the patronage of Congress for the publication of his book, and remuneration for the expenses and labours of his researches. He saw last Evening Mr Calhoun, who took a deep interest in his invention— He proposed that it should be explained to a select meeting of members of both Houses—named several members of the Senate, and suggested that Mr Cushing and I should name such members of the House, as would take pleasure in attending such a meeting— I marked down the names of several members of the House, and gave the list to Mr Cushing to select from the list, and add others as he should see fit— I told him that for my part I should be glad if our whole delegation were of the number— At 11. O’Clock on going in to the House we found they had been an hour in Session— Titus of New-York—Pope and Bond had successively moved the suspension of the Rules, for Resolutions to fix a day to consider Bills, extending the benefit of the Pension Laws—but all without success— Birdsall from the Committee of Revolutionary claims had reported adversely to several memorials and among the rest to that of the Heirs of Major General John Thomas for Bounty Lands— Thomas Chairman of the Judiciary Committee had reported without amendment a penal Bill from the Senate. A number of private Bills which had been postponed to this day were now taken up, briefly discussed and almost all rejected— Upon the Bill for the relief of the representatives of Coll. Francis Vigo, the Committee of the whole had struck out a clause, allowing interest to three or four times the amount of the original debt— It was one case of a multitude in which the select Committee had allowed from 50 to 60 years of interest—all which the Committee of the whole had invariably struck out— This case was supposed to be stronger than all the rest, because the Sovereign State of Virginia had
had a concern in it— In this debate I took a part for concurring with the Committee of the whole to strike out the allowance of interest, and the House did concur by yeas and nays 86 to 56— Sundry other Bills were taken up and postponed, when upon a question to concur with the Committee of the whole in striking out the enacting clause of one of them the vote was 46 to 19. only 65 members voting— It was just after 2 O’Clock, and the House adjourned for want of a Quorum. I had ordered Thomas to come for me at 4. the heat of the Sun being too intense for a walk of two miles in the middle of the day; I therefore remained after the adjournment, in my Seat, and began a Letter in answer to one from Origen Bacheler— I had written only the first page when Isaac Fletcher a member from Vermont and Williams a member from Maine came, and sat down by me, and commenced a conversation with me, which continued till past 4. It consisted entirely of enquiries made by them, about men and things with which I have been heretofore conversant in Europe, and in this Country, and of my answers which were garrulous— They both told me they were natives of Massachusetts—Williams, of the town of Plymouth— He said he had been there last Summer, and in passing by my house had seen that built by my Son upon the Hill. Immediately after they left me I found Thomas waiting for me and came home— Evening warm.
10. V. Sunday.

My wife had another almost sleepless night with continual coughing, but is better— The Erisypelas fire beginning to come out on the surface— Mary has also a very severe cold, and her daughter Mary-Louisa is in drooping health never wholly recovered from the Meazles— Fanny went with me to the morning service at the Presbyterian Church; where Mr Fowler preached from Romans 5.6. [“]For when we were yet without strength, in due time Christ died for the ungodly”— The atonement. There is an artificial system of reasoning connected with this subject which baffles all human reason. Mr Fowler averred that the whole Christian dispensation was in these words— Why should Christ die for the ungodly? why not make them godly without dying? why are any ungodly, after he died with intent to save them? How can the omnipotence of God be reconciled with the perverseness of man?— How is it possible that so many men with clear heads and clean hearts can believe such preposterous absurdities? It is the frailty of human reason, and its only practical lesson is toleration— Miss Johnston dined with us. After dinner I went alone to St. John’s, where Mr Hawley read the Evening service, for Trinity Sunday, and preached from Isaiah 11.9. [“]They shall not hurt nor destroy, in all in my holy mountain: for the earth shall be full of the knowledge of the Lord, as the waters cover the Sea.”— Mr Hawley seems to be as fond of taking his texts from Isaiah, as Mr Fowler is from St. Paul— Of all the Books of the old Testament, that of Isaiah has to me the most attractive charm. He wrote in the days of Uzziah, Jotham, Ahaz and Hezekiah kings of Judah— A series of visions during a space of nearly half a century—predicting the ruin of the kingdoms of Israel and Judah, and the subsequent glories of the Messiah, and of his kingdom— It is the most cheering book in the world to those who believe in the improvable capacity of the human race— It promises the final extinction of War and Slavery from
from the face of the Earth— It is a collection of prophesies to which the occasions whence they originated are merely incidental— The 6th. chapter tells of a vision in the year that king Uzziah died— The 7th. in the days of Ahaz— Subsequent chapters are prophesies against Babylon, Moab, Syria, Egypt, Ethiopia, Assyria, Edom, Tyre, Ephraim (the kingdom of Israel) till the 36th. Chapter, which commences with the Assyrian invasion of Judah in the 14th. year of Hezekiah— This same event is related in the second Book of Kings 18th. Chapter, beginning at the 13th. verse and more briefly in the 32d. chapter of the 2d. Book of Chronicles— The sickness and recovery of Hezekiah—the embassy from Merodach-Baladan, king of Babylon—the kind reception of them by Hezekiah, who shews them his Treasures, and the appalling prophesy of the Babylonian captivity with the meek if not abject resignation of Hezekiah, conclude with the 39th. chapter, immediately followed by that unparalleled sublimity of the 40th. chapter “Comfort ye, comfort ye my People”—and the proclamation of the Messiah— The reign of Uzziah, or Azariah began 810 years before Christ—that of Jotham 758—of Ahaz 742—of Hezekiah 726. and of Manasseh 698— The prophesy of the 6th. chapter was therefore in 758. That of the 7th. chapter in 742— That of the 36th. chapter in 713. and that of the 39th. chapter about 710. There is no prophesy of Isaiah of a later date than this— There is nothing of the Aristotelian doctrine of the unities in the composition of the Hebrew prophets. The Book of Isaiah is a collection of Rhapsodies, delivered in a course of 50 years—prophesying first events to happen in and to the kingdom of Judah, and other cotemporaneous Asiatic and African Nations—but secondly the advent—the life and death of Christ, and the universal prevalence of his dominion upon earth— We know not why these two descriptions of prophesies were thus associated together. It is not clear that Isaiah himself or any other of the Prophets of the Old Testament, had any conception of the manner in which their predictions were to be fulfilled— More than 700 years were to pass away, when the 40th. chapter was composed, before Christ should be born, and he, the Lord of worlds, the redeemer of the human race, the Sovereign of man, and of Creation, was to be born in the stable of an Inn, the son of a Carpenter, tributary to Rome. How wonderful— How passing wonder—how worthy of Meditation! Mr Frye was here this Evening.— Fahrenheit 122 in the Sun 85 in the shade.
11. IV:15. Monday.

A woman named Elizabeth Pierce had come without money, from Rhode-Island, in search of Land claims, without knowing what they were, or how or where, or when to apply for them— She had applied to Tristam Burges, who had given her in writing the name of some other person to apply to— She had written to Daniel Webster, whose answer promising his aid she shewed me—and she came to me with a list of names and sums of final Settlement certificates in the revolutionary War— I referred her to the Commissioner of the Land-Office whose name I gave her and told her where the Office was— At last she asked for Mrs Adams, who I told her was confined to her bed by illness— She intimated that what she wanted was money— She afterwards came again to the Capitol—had me called from my Seat in the House—shewed me another set of sums without names, which she said was all
all she could get at the Land Office— That Mr Webster had been very short with her and told her he had very important business to attend to; and that she had not a cent of money— I gave her a five dollar bill, and advised her to apply again at the Land Office— I attended at the Committee of Manufactures Mr Slade was the only other member of the Committee who attended— No Quorum, and we adjourned to Thursday— The States and Territories were called for Resolutions beginning with Wisconsin— The rule of alternating on Mondays the Call for Petitions and Resolutions, with that excluding debate upon either on any of those days, has proved a great accommodation to the receipt both of Petitions and Resolutions— Yet they were trammelled this day by the special order to take up the business relating to the District of Columbia, at 12. O’Clock— The States were called through for Resolutions but not for Petitions A number of the workmen upon the public buildings sent and called me out from my seat, and asked me to present a petition from them stating their distress from the suspension of their work, and praying for relief— When 12. O’Clock came, Bouldin, bustled for the special order, and moved to go into Committee of the House— I asked leave to present a Petition. He objected— I said it related to the business of the District of Columbia— He then withdrew his objection— I presented the Petition, and moved that it should be read— It was read. I moved it should be printed, and referred to the Committee of the whole who had the business of the District before them— Thomas moved to take up the motion of reconsideration pending upon the Treasury building Bill, and by settling that question, put the workmen again immediately upon wages.— He carried it by a vote of two thirds— Harrison moved to lay the motion to reconsider on the table—lost 86 to 100— Yell called for the yeas and nays on the reconsideration—103 to 91— Motion to lay the Bill on the table, lost. Amendments proposed. Cushman moves to lay the Bill and amendments on the table—lost, 95 to 98— More discussion on the Bill and amendments, and then another motion by Petrikin to lay the whole on the table—carried 94 to 91— It was at last a close party vote: and it was determined to continue the building as begun, to escape the reproach of having spent so much money upon it, and then taking it down— Wise stung them into the final vote, by calling it the House that Jack built; and running a parallel between its unfinished unfinishable half erected ruin, and the late and present administration— Between the first vote of 86 to 100 and the last of 94 to 91. The mutes of the administration party were moving round the house and rallying the stragglers to the fold. The building will be continued at an enormous expense—but whether ever finished is doubtful, and whether it will stand if finished is more so— It is now unequivocally an administration building, though several administration members voted for taking it down, and about an equal number of the opposition against it— Wise’s house that Jack built settled the question— I offered a Resolution that Wednesday the 20th. instt at one O’Clock be assigned for the consideration of Bills from the Senate numbered 147. 175 and 176. reported by the Committee of Manufactures without amendment— The Speaker said it would require a vote of two thirds— I explained that these were bills for the remission of duties, peculiarly interesting
interesting to the States of Georgia and Alabama; but no one of the members from either of those States supported me, and the vote for the assignment was 61 to 68— Among the Resolutions offered was a series of 8 upon the late Mississippi elections, and the proceedings of the House upon them, which lie over and were ordered to be printed—presented by S. S. Prentiss— Howard moved a call on the Secy. of the Treasury for returns of receipts and payments in the several States in 1837.— Hopkins moved to add, in 1833–34–35. and I moved to add in 1836— So the resolution passed, Cushing moved an instruction of enquiry to the Committee of Manufactures concerning books— Several other Resolutions were offered, and adopted or laid over, on various subjects interesting or otherwise— Explanation about the Bill for the relief of William Wickham— A reconveyance gratuitous to him of a Fishery, appurtenant to land which he sold three or four years since to U.S— The moment the district of Columbia Bills were taken up, there was no quorum— Two thirds of the day were consumed in counting the members present, finding no quorum; reporting the fact to the house— Motions to adjourn; calls of the house; sending for stragglers—making just a Quorum: Going into Committee again, and Petrikin making questions to count votes and find no quorum— Through all this Bouldin by dint of confused agitation and humble supplication succeeded to get two very insignificant Bills relating to the District, reported to the House, which about 7 O’Clock adjourned. When the motion to rise and report the Bills was made Thomas moved to take up the Bill prohibiting the Chesapeake and Ohio Canal Corporation from issuing Bills of less than 5 dollars. Underwood the Chairman decided that after the motion to rise and report the Bills it was not in order to move to take up any other Bill— He was supported in this by Linn Banks, Patton’s Successor, and late Speaker of the House in the Virginia Legislature. I contested the point on the practice of the House, but did not appeal from the Speaker’s decision—
12. IV:30. Tuesday.

Mr Frye was here this morning, with information that the new Stone dam, at the Columbian Mills was finished, and ready to be examined by two inspectors—whom he said he would name and engage to do the service to-morrow. At 9 O’Clock I attended a Meeting of about 20 members of both Houses of Congress in the chamber of the Committee of Foreign Relations; before whom Dr. Sherwood with the assistance of Mr Sereno Dwight, explained again the theory of his magnetic discoveries.— That he has made discoveries cannot be doubted— That of magnetising a ring for example— But whether the magnetic poles are on the arctic and antarctic circles—whether the range of variation of the needle is 23 degrees 28 minutes and above all whether the variation is in a straight line from the Poles to the equator so as infallibly to indicate the Latitude and Longitude of every place, there is not yet sufficient evidence to shew. The immense magnitude of the claim requires a proportional certitude of proof. I cannot resist incredulity. H.R.U.S. Grennell, by suspension of the rules carried a motion that from and after this day, the House would daily take a recess from 2 to 1/2 past 3 O’Clock, an amendment was moved to make it from 1/2 past 2 till 4—but the previous question drove through, the original motion. Elisha Whittlesey moved a suspension of the rules to offer
offer a Resolution that the pay of every member should be stopped for the day, who shall not answer to his name at the first call of the House Yeas and nays on the suspension 89 to 98— Reports were received from the Committees and then came the pre-emption Bill in Committee of the whole on the Union— Randolph of New-Jersey had the floor and finished a long speech against the Bill— Then Harrison of Missouri, Lincoln, Pope, Underwood, Lyon, Mason of Ohio and Garland of Louisiana, warmly debated the Bill— Garland moved an entire Bill as a substitute— Underwood a long amendment— At the invitation of Mr Elisha Whittlesey and Mr Taliaferro, I dined with them in a small room adjoining that of the Committee of claims— Mr Swift, a Senator from Vermont was also there— Returning to the House, I found Mason of Ohio, still speaking on the pre-emption Bill— Casey of Illinois, and Crary of Michigan followed Mason, and gave the whole theory of the Settlers on the public Lands—which is that the only just right to land is occupancy and labour, and that this right is individual as well as social— That every man has a right to take up unoccupied land; and having taken it up has the right to purchase the right of the community at the lowest price, and in preference to all others. Crary compared the right of the Squatter on Land, to the right of the fisherman upon the Ocean— It was a common right, and the fisherman was a squatter upon the water, just as the Settler is a squatter upon the land— This is the tone of opinion throughout the new Western States, and so thoroughly is the sense of right and wrong in the human heart subservient to the physical wants of the human animal, that this utter perversion of the elementary principle of property passes throughout the western region for irrefragable logic— I take no part in this debate— The public Lands are irrecoverably lost, and it were a worthless and a thankless task to intermeddle in the scramble for the spoils— W. B. Carter of Tennessee failed in his oft repeated motion to suspend the rules, to fix a day for the discussion of the Pension Bills— The House adjourned at 6. P.M. returning home, I called for Mary at Mrs Thornton’s, and paid a visit to Dr Huntt, who looks like a living corpse, but in this fair Summer weather thinks his strength recruited—
13. IV:30. Wednesday

Note from Mrs Stewart; about Stapylton’s life of Canning, and the foreign quarterly review—Peru and other affairs, with a request that I would call in as I did— But I could not answer her enquiries not even with regard to the condition of her mother’s claim, which was the ultimatum of her wish to see me Call at the Pension Office—left with Mr Edwards the Letters of Major Charles Larrabee and ofPhelps, requesting him to furnish me with the information necessary to answer them— Visit to Mr Silsbee at Fuller’s— Saw him and his two daughters. They are going to the Virginia white Sulphur Springs— Mr Legare came in while I was there— H.R.U.S. Reports of Committees— Legare from the Committee of Foreign Affairs. presented his Report upon the Petitions from the Peace Societies, which he had shewn me, and which I had rend— Ten thousand extra copies of it were ordered to be printed, opposed only by Petrikin. Then Dromgoole from the same Committee, reported a Resolution that
that the Committee be discharged from the consideration of all the Resolutions of State Legislatures, and of the Memorials and Petitions of individuals relating to the annexation of Texas to the United States, and that they be laid on the Table.— Cushing another member of the Committee, objected to the report, and offered a Resolution that the report be recommitted with instructions to report upon the merits of the Resolutions and Memorials and Petitions referred—some debate arose— I enquired, if the Committee had given five minutes of consideration to the Resolutions of State Legislatures, and the Multitudes of Petitions and Memorials referred to them— Droomgoole immediately rose and denied my right to ask the question and said he would not be catechised by me— I said that was enough for me— The refusal to answer would warrant me and the People in the inference that the Committee never did consider the subject referred to them— Carter of Tennessee, opposed Cushing’s Resolution; and Pickens of South-Carolina supported it— Cushman said a proposition to annex an independent republic to this Union should come from that republic— No such proposition was before the House— The debate was irregular, and he moved the previous question— Confusion and Laughter. I asked him to withdraw the motion, to allow an answer to his Speech— He refused; but the vote upon his motion was 74 to 81. no second; and Howard, Chairman of the Committee of foreign Affairs took the floor— The hour had elapsed, and the Committee of the whole on the state of the Union took up again the pre-emption Bill— Chapman of Alabama and Prentiss of Mississippi made long Speeches in favour of the Bill, and Robertson of Virginia part of a Speech against it— The heat was so intense that through the day I was often obliged to leave my Seat, and go to breathe at one of the windows— Mr C. S. Daveis called me from my Seat, and enquired where he could find, my discussion of the right to the fisheries to which Howard of Maryland had lately referred with commendation in a Speech— This commendation had been excessive; but I did not know to what he had specially alluded— I asked Howard what it was and he said it was the discussion in the pamphlet I had published— I took Mr Daveis into the Library, and there found the pamphlet— The Duplicate Letters, the Fisheries and the Mississippi, and pointed out to him page 184. the passage to which Howard had referred. I shewed himself also my two Letters on the right to the fisheries in Gales and Seatons State papers Foreign Relations Vol. 4. pages 352 and 356. He said Mr Webster wished to see those papers, and would make a Speech tomorrow on the North-eastern boundary Bill— The time of the recess from 2 to 1/2 past 3 I spent in the chamber of the Committee of manufactures, and finished a Letter in answer to Origen Bacheler, declining the invitation to address the Peace Society on my passage through New-York— At the meeting after the recess Robertson finished his Speech against the pre-emption Bill, and Cushing followed with a Speech in its favour Cushing avowed the most licentious of the doctrines subversive of property, and the most comprehensive principles of the right of individual occupancy He takes his cue from Webster, and hazards opinions unpopular now in our State and Section, but which he knows will prevail here, and against which he sees that all resistance is vain— Rice Garland made two or more Speeches for his substitute, for the Bill and a multitude of petty amendments were moved, debated, and adopted
adopted or rejected— Two or three votes taken without a Quorum, and at last by common consent the bill and amendments were reported to the House, more by lassitude of hearing than exhaustion of eloquence— Adjourned at 1/2 past 8— Near 10 when I got home.
