div.p: 14. IV:15. Thursday

Meeting of the Committee of Manufactures. Present, Adams, Naylor, Slade, Tillinghast, Vail, Webster— Absent Biddle, Foster and Hunter— I was instructed to prepare a Bill, remitting the duties on iron for two Steamboats, imported by G. B. Lamar and the bonds on one for the Georgia Steam boat Company— Resolution of 11. June instructing the Committee to enquire into the expediency of providing by Law for adding to the Treasury returns of commerce and Navigation the books produced in the United States—to lie for further consideration, and to enquire what Mr Cushing, who offered the Resolution, understands by Books produced in the United States.— H.R.U.S. Great part of the morning hour, was consumed in Motions to suspend the Rules, to fix a day of adjournment, and to make a special order for considering the Bills to extend the Pension Laws—lost by yeas and nays—the first 82 to 55. the second 88 to 81. in neither case two thirds— The Texas question coming up, Waddy Thompson moved an Amendment to Cushing’s Resolution—to recommit the report of the Committee with instructions—to strike out all after that word and insert, “to report a joint Resolution directing the President to take the necessary steps for the annexation of Texas to the United States, as soon as it can be done consistently with the Treaty stipulations of this Government.”— Howard then began a Speech chiefly in answer to Mr Cushing’s remarks in support of his Resolution to recommit the report— His main argument was that there was no proposition for the annexation of Texas before the house; but that argument now failed— Thompson’s proposition having brought a proposition directly before the House— Howard said he regretted that Cushman’s motion for the previous Question yesterday did not prevail— That the proposition from Texas itself had been promptly rejected— And he intimated that Thompson by precipitating the recognition of the Texian Independence had greatly increased the difficulty and retarded the possibility of effecting the annexation— Howard had not finished when the hour expired and the pre-emption Bill was taken up— It was debated the whole day with much pertinacity, and Governor Lincoln, the only member of the Committee on the public Lands, representing an interest to preserve them as the property of the People, obtained with the assistance of Briggs two or three palliative amendments, which I believe not worth contending for— The thirst of a tyger for blood, is the fittest emblem of the rapacity with which the members of all the new States fly at the Public Lands— The constituents upon whom they depend are all Settlers, or tame and careless spectators of the pillage— They are themselves enormous speculators and Land-jobbers— It were a vain attempt to resist them here— The heat was so intense, that I could not remain in my Seat— I found on my table a note from Mr Daveis expressing a wish that I would go into the Senate chamber, and hear Mr Webster speaking upon the North-eastern boundary question— I went accordingly and heard him upon the
the Northwest Angle of Nova-Scotia— His exposition was clear and unquestionable, but his hearers apparently took little interest in it— Mr Preston to whom I returned the sketch of a projected picture for the Rotunda, which he had some time since left with me, pressed me to take his seat as he was going out— I took it—Mr Buchanan came behind me and whispered—the worst of it is, there is no doubt—an oracular sentence of which I did not ask the explanation— Buchanan is chairman of the Senate’s Committee of Forign Affairs, and when Mr Webster finished, moved to postpone the subject till Saturday when he would make some proposition— I then left the Senate chamber, and found the members of the House—dispersing for the recess—which I passed in the chamber of the Committee of Manufactures writing part of a Letter— After the recess, the pre-emption Bill was again taken up and passed— Governor Lincoln and Briggs, succeeded in carrying amendments confining the operation of the Bill to the benefit of actual bone fide settlers— They were vehemently opposed by Crary and Casey, and the Western members, whose tactics are to abuse without mercy the speculator in debate, and to oppose every possible expedient to guard against them— Underwood moved to recommit the Bill to a Committee of a member from each State with instructions to report a land Bill, for the distribution of the proceeds of the public Lands—which after an abortive motion from Cushman for the previous question, was rejected by yeas and nays—79 to 123. May proposed an amendment giving a general license to every one to settle on the public Lands and after a year’s occupancy, a right of pre-emption to one quarter Section. This and sundry other amendments were rejected, as was repeatedly the Previous Question; but that was at last moved by Boon and carried—the vote for engrossment was 132 to 70. and that for the final passage of the Bill 107 to 52— Adjourned after 9. in the evening—10 when I got home. Excessive heat drove me frequently to the windows for breath.
15. IV:15. Friday.

Wilkins and Cole two of the workmen on the Treasury building came to enquire of the fate of their petition, which I presented for them last Monday— They thought it was to obtain for them their pay for the time while the work was suspended— But the Petition had not asked for that. It had only stated their distressed condition, and prayed generally for relief— They had been set to work the very next day, and that was considered as a compliance with the prayer of their petition— I told them that if they claimed their pay for the suspended time it must be by another petition—and if they would have one prepared by next Monday, I would present it, and do what I could to promote its success— H.R.U.S. Snyder of Illinois made a very formal and equally foolish address to the House, on a newspaper Article in yesterday’s Madisonian, charging him in substance with having sold his promise to vote for the sub-treasury, for a promise of place— He denied the fact— Said he was not a candidate for office, had received no Executive smiles— The charge was false and slanderous; but he should take no further notice of it, inasmuch as the Editor of the Madisonian had forfeited the pledge under which he had been elected Printer to the House; of supporting the present administration, and the usages of the Republican party— The charges in the Madisonian against Mr Snyder, of fishing for office with the bait of the sub-treasury, I am told are all true.
H.R.U.S— Dromgoole’s report concerning Texas is now the regular business of the morning hour— Before Howard resumed his argument I offered an amendment to Waddy Thompson’s Amendment—to strike out all after the word Instructions and insert to report the following Resolutions— That the power of annexing the People of a foreign Government to this Union, has not been delegated to the Congress nor to any department of the Government of the United States but has been reserved to the People— That any attempt by Act of Congress or by Treaty to annex the Republic of Texas to this Union would be an usurpation of power, which it would be the right, and the duty of the Free People of the Union to resist and annul— This, being an amendment to an amendment gives me the right to the floor immediately after Howard— He finished his Speech against the recommitment, and all the instructions— Petrikin moved to lay the whole subject on the Table—but withdrew the motion, first for an explanation from Cushing, and afterwards generally by request— Waddy Thompson told me two or three days since that we should have the Texas discussion, for that it had been promised to him. All the South Carolinians desire it— I enquired of Howard as Chairman of the Committee whether he sustained Dromgoole in his refusal to answer whether the Committee had taken into consideration the Resolutions, Petitions and Memorials relating to Texas referred to them by the House— Howard answered that he did— That it was disrespectful to the Committee to ask such questions, and he should go the whole length of the Gentleman from Virginia, and refuse to answer— I then put the question to Ogden Hoffman another member of the Committee who was standing before me, and said I should be glad to put it to every member of the Committee—but the Speaker interposed and anounced the orders of the day, without allowing even Hoffman time to answer— This gave me however the floor for tomorrow— The house then went into the consideration of private business; to which it was impossible for me to give much attention— Mr Daveis the agent from the State of Maine asked to have some conversation with me during the recess, and was with me, the whole time in the chamber of the Committee of Manufactures: giving me an account of his conversations with Mr Poinsett on the boundary question— With Forsyth he is utterly disgusted— He consulted me with great anxiety, about what he was to do, and wrote down a proviso, which he had thoughts of proposing to modify the Bill for surveying the boundary— I gave him freely my advice—which was to let such proviso come from the administration side— He said that Mr Reuel Williams was convinced that the Bill would not pass— After the recess there was a call of the House and an exact Quorum answered to their names— The Bills for the relief of Coll. Vigo, and of Mrs Ann Heileman passed by large majorities; the latter much increased by an eloquent appeal to the patriotism and humanity of the house by James M Mason— Mr Bigelow, the agent for the Casaux claim, came and pleaded very hard with me in favour of it— He said that two of Casaux’s sons, had passed the winter here in anxious pursuit of the claim— And he most earnestly intreated my attention to the Report of Virgil Maxcy, late Solicitor of the Treasury, of 16 June 1836. on the claim, which he gave me.— The House adjourned at 7. Mr Rariden, member of the House from Indiana, introduced to me two Quaker travellers from that State— Coll Towson had invited me to his house to-morrow at 1. O’Clock, to taste to certain native American wines in behalf of the horticultural Society— He changed the hour this day to 2—for the recess.
16. IV. Saturday

H.R.U.S. After some little trickery to consume the time of the house in motions out of order and to suspend the rules, for other purposes, I obtained the floor, on the motion to recommit the report of the Committee of Foreign Relations concerning Texas— Tillinghast asked me to give way for the reading of the Resolutions from the Legislature of Rhode-Island against the annexation; I told him it was my purpose to notice them and have them read in the progress of their remarks on this occasion—whereupon he desisted and I commenced my argument, and continued until the expiration of the hour when the orders of the day were announced and private business was taken up— I confined myself entirely to the points made by Dromgoole, Howard, and Legare, and my Speech was only an animated dialogue with them upon the right of Petition— I am oppressed by the magnitude and weight of the subject, and anxious even to dejection with regard to the mode of treating it best suited to the magnitude success of the cause— Instead of private business, the day was occupied with two Bills from the Senate relating to the explosions of Steamboats— At the recess Mr Gouverneur Kemble went with me to Coll. Towson’s—where a large party were invited to taste a variety of wines from indigenous American grapes compared with Madeira, Champagne, Rhenish and Sherry— They had been sent as Samples to the horticultural Society of which Coll. Towson is President; and a Committee of whom I was chairman, was appointed to taste them— President Van Buren, Messrs. Woodbury, Poinsett and Dickerson Genl Jesup just returned from Florida, Sundry members of the Senate, Speaker Polk, and many members of the House of Representatives were there—a Table was laid, not for a dinner, nor even for a collation; but with relishes for tasting the wines— Cold Tongue, Cheese, Bologna Sausages, Olives &c—and a few very fine looking Strawberries were handed round of which each would have been able to take one or two. The President Soon withdrew, and after tasting six or seven variety among the wines, of which two were called Champagne, I retired also with G. Kemble, and went and dined with him— Howard was there and immediately after dinner went off with Mr Latrobe, by the Cars to Baltimore— There was another young man who dined with us. Mr Kemble returned with me to the House, which we found in Committee of the whole Davee in the Chair, on the two Bills from the Senate purposing to guard against Steamboat explosions— An absurd Constitutional scruple of Robertson of Virginia, led him to offer an Amendment excepting Steam boats navigating within the waters of a State—and this made a debate of half a day, and actually prevented for this time the passage of the Bill— Robertson’s amendment and others congenial to it bred in the compost of fermenting debate were rejected, but the passage of the Bill was postponed— The other Bill was reported to the House and passed— Adjourned at 1/2 past 6 I heard for half an hour the Marine Corps band from the Eastern front steps of the Capitol and walked home— I took out from the Library the 3d. volume of Jefferson’s writings, to use in my argument— The 4th volume of both sets was out and I could not obtain it. I find it impossible to continue my Diary at large from day to day, and must henceforth, either break it off again as I have so often done before, or confine it to mere index minutes till days of more leisure shall return.
17. IV. Sunday

Took Fanny with me to Church this Morning. Heard Mr Fowler from John 12.32. “And I, if I be lifted up from the earth will draw all men unto me.”— After dinner I went alone to St. John’s. Mr Hawley read the service for the first Sunday after Trinity, and a Stranger preached, from Isaiah 55:6. “Seek ye the Lord, while he may be found; call ye upon him, while he is near.”— Received a Letter from Mr Frye, with notice that the new Mill dam has been inspected and found completed according to the contract. and asking for a check to complete the payment.
18. III:45. Monday

Called at Mr Frye’s Office, and left with him an answer to his Letter, and a check— Committee of Manufactures at 9. Present, Adams, Biddle, Naylor, Slade, Tillinghast, Vail, Webster— Bill prepared for remitting duties on Iron Steam-boats imported by G. B. Lamar, and the Georgia Steamboat Company— While I was in Committee, two of the workmen, on the public buildings, came to the room and called me out, and requested me to present a Petition for them to the House, praying for their wages during the time that the work upon the Treasury building was suspended— H.R.U.S— Nearly three hours consumed on a question to reconsider the reference of a Memorial from F. P. Blair about the public printing to a select Committee— This had become so thoroughly a party concern, that the question of its reference to the Committees on Public expenditures and the Post-Office, or to a select Committee was twice decided by yeas and nays—first 89. and 89. the Speaker giving the casting vote, and secondly by 101. to 100— The reference was to a select Committee to be appointed by the Speaker. I presented the petition of the workmen, which was read, ordered to be printed and referred to the Committee on the Public buildings. I presented also a Petition from Abington, concerning the Cherokee Indians— Laid on the table. I asked leave to offer a Resolution of Call on P.U.S. for the Newspaper, stated by the late Texian Minister Huntt in his Letter ofSeptember 1837. to be sent with that Letter to the Secretary of State, or a copy of the Report of a Committee of the House of Representatives of the State of Mississippi, alledged to be contained in that paper.—but my Resolution was not admitted— Recess— P.M. Post-Office Bill in Committee of the whole Davee in the Chair— Thunder shower after a warm day— Adjourned past 8.
19. IV. Tuesday.

Three sets of workmen on the Treasury building applied to me to obtain the payment of their wages during the time when their work was suspended. The two whose Petition I presented yesterday, who came to enquire if I had presented it— They were Stone-cutters and carpenters— Then three a Committee from the Bricklayers, who brought me their petition this morning, which I presented by leave, and which was ordered to be printed, and referred to the Committee on the Public
Public buildings, and two others, came to the House, and had me called from my seat, to say that although their names were not subscribed to either of the Petitions, they had the same claim and wished it equally to be considered. I referred them all to Governor Lincoln, chairman of the Committee on the Public Buildings.— I continued during the morning hour my Speech against the annexation of Texas— This morning I discussed the composition of the Committee of Foreign Affairs in two points of View. 1. As representing North and South. 2 as Administration and Opposition— Orders of the day— Committee of the whole on the State of the Union. Connor in the Chair— Independent Treasury Bill— That is what they call it now. Introduced by Cambreleng in a short Speech— Supported by Pickens in a long one, full of inflammatory sophistry.— Recess— Upon returning, Garland of Virginia, asked indulgence till to-morrow, for his speech against the Independent Treasury Bill— Committee of the whole on the Union rose— The House immediately went into Committee of the whole on the Union again, Davee in the Chair, on the Post-Office and Post route Bill, which was debated—amended, and reported to the House— Adjourned at 7.— I went to the Theatre and saw the Wedding day, or my first Wife, a very wretched Farce— Miss Virginia Monier performing the part of Lady Contest— Then Ion a celebrated modern Tragedy by Serjeant Thomas Noon Talfourd—the part of Ion by Ellen Tree— Met there—W. R. King Charles S. Daveis, and Archibald Campbell who came home with me at Midnight.
20. IV:15. Wednesday

Call at the Department of State for the Newspaper, sent by the Texian Envoy Extraordinary and Minister Plenipotentiary, last September to Mr Forsyth, and containing the Report of the Committee of the House of Representatives of the State of Mississippi to that body on the annexation of Texas to this Union— Neither Mr Forsyth, nor the Chief Clerk Dayton was at the Office; but the diplomatic Clerk was there, and could not find Mr Memucan Hunt’s Newspaper. It was mislaid. H.R.U.S. My Speech on Texas— Reviewed the Resolutions of the State Legislatures—Rhode-Island, Ohio—Tennessee—Michigan—stopp’d at Alabama. Vermont had been introduced yesterday— Resolutions of the Rhode-Island Legislature not printed in the Journal— Explanations with Tillinghast— Hamer asked my leave to present a petition—granted, reminding him of his refusal to me of the same courtesy yesterday— Independent Treasury Bill— James Garland’s speech against it, and his substitute— Bronson’s proposed Amendment—to strike out Calhouns specie Section. and suspend the Laws against small Bills— Recess— I passed it in the Library searching in vain for the report of the Committee of the Mississippi House of Representatives, on the annexation of Texas— After the recess Dromgoole’s Speech for the Sub treasury Bill— S.S. Prentiss began his Speech against it— Adjourned At 7. Walk home— Theatre, with my wife—Mary, and her daughter Mary-Louisa—and Archibald Campbell— The Wife— Ellen Tree. Mariana, Youthful Queen. Christine Kemble, Howard there. House thin.
21. V. Thursday

Meeting of the Committee of Manufactures— Present, Adams, Naylor, Tillinghast, Vail, Webster— Question of reporting a Bill to levy a duty of 2. cents per lb on Starch considered and postponed— Much favoured by Naylor. H.R.U.S— Morning hour—continued my Speech on the Texian question— Tillinghast. The Resolutions of the Legislature of Rhode-Island, presented on the 29th. of December last, and omitted then to be printed on the Journal, are to be printed on the Journal of this day. Nunc pro Tunc— Cushing modifies his resolution so as to insert the two additional State Legislatures, Vermont and Rhode Island— I review the Preamble and Resolutions of the Legislature of Alabama— Their personal attack on me— Resolutions of the Legislature of Massachusetts—proceedings in New-York and Pennsylvania— Debate in the Texian Congress— Interrupted while reading it— Harlan calls for the orders of the day— Committee of the Whole on the Union, Connor in the Chair on the Independent Treasury Bill— Duncan proposes an amendment— S. S. Prentiss till the recess, and two hours of the Evening Session against the Bill— Rhett and R. M. T. Hunter take the floor— Committee rise and house adjourn at 6:30.— Part walk home— Theatre, with my wife, Mary—both her Children and A. Campbell— The Love-Chase, a Comedy by J. Knowles— Constance by Ellen Tree and Wildrake by Fredericks, with Perfection, or the Maid of Munster— Ellen Tree as Kate O’Brien and Fredericks, as Charles Paragon— Both indifferent plays— An alarm of fire made some disturbance which soon subsided— It was the benefit night of Miss Tree, and the house was crowded. A gloom spread over the House and City by the account of the Destruction of the Steamer Pulaski, by explosion of the Engine, and loss of near 200 lives— There was also an accident happened last evening to the Railway Cars, from Baltimore; which were thrown off the track by running over a Cow. Mr Southard the Senator from New Jersey, was in one of the Cars, and slightly bruised by the operation. He told me of it, on the floor of the House, behind the bar this day.
22— V:30. Friday.

Dr Chapin, President of the Columbian College in the District of Columbia; with a Dr Sherwood one of the Professors at that Institution called on me this morning to speak about the Smithsonian bequest— Mr Rush has recovered the money—half a Million of Dollars, and is expected, with it here in the course of the next Month— Dr Chapin represented that if this money should be applied to the foundation of a College or University, it must necessarily effect the total Destruction of his College— I told him that after the passage of the Act of Congress, for procuring the money, I had not permitted myself to think upon the subject till the money should be in the Treasury— That I hoped however no disposal of the fund would be made which would in any manner injure the Columbian College— That I did not think the Smithsonian Institution should be a College or a University, or a school of education for children—but altogether of a different character— That as the money would come into the hands of the Executive I hoped the President would in his next annual message propose some plan for the adoption of Congress for the disposal of the fund, and I advised Dr Chapin to see the President and
and converse with him on the subject, which he said he would. H.R.U.S. Texas and the morning hour. Concluded my remarks on the debate in the Texian Congress—proceedings in the Legislatures of New-York and Pennsylvania—and South-Carolina— Duty of the Committee to take all these Resolutions into Consideration. System of suppression— Legare calls me to order. Speaker decides I may proceed— Enumeration of the subjects upon which debate has been suppressed— Hour expires— Independent Treasury Bill. R. M. T. Hunter for it until, and again after the recess. John P. Kennedy the new member from Baltimore in the place of M’Kim, begins a powerful speech against it. Committee rise— Steam-boat explosion Bill— Sundry amendments proposed. ridiculous Constitutional objections. Adjourn at 7:15. Several of the workmen at the Treasury building came to enquire of the prospects of their petitions. At my request Governor Lincoln notified a meeting of the Committee on the public buildings for Monday morning which they may attend— The husband of Mrs Goode’s daughter Ellen, married but a few weeks since died this day of a fever.

23. IV:15. Saturday. Miriam the prophetess— Her timbrel—her Song—and all the women after her— H.R.U.S. Morning hour— Texas— On the system of suppression— I alluded to the transactions in the House from 6 to 11. Feby 1837. Slave petitioning— I was called to order by Legare, and peremptorily stopped by the Speaker— I called on the Speaker to have the disorderly words taken down. He refuses I appeal from his decision— He is sustained by the yeas and nays 115 to 36—205 members in the House— I resumed speaking for one minute— Sherrod Williams moves a reconsideration of the vote of yesterday postponing the resolution to fix the day of adjournment, and assigned what had taken place this morning as evidence that the Session was getting to be too long— The postponement was reconsidered, and the Resolution to adjourn the 9th. of July passed— Independent Treasury Bill— John P. Kennedy till and an hour after the recess— Toucey’s flabby eloquence for the Bill— Waddy Thompson against it— Potter a Pennsylvanian Irishman began some very brief remarks for it— After hearing him nearly an hour; at 1/2 past 7. I saw he would not finish before 9 and that no question would be taken to Night— So I left the Committee of the whole in Session, and went to the Theatre— Saw Shakespear’s As you like it— Ellen Tree, for Rosalind— All the other parts wretchedly performed— Jaques by Frederick’s who had no conception of the part— Left out some of the finest passages spoke some, set down for others, and delivered with lifeless insipidity the 7. ages. Pickering’s Touchstone was rather better but not good. The play itself so admirable in the closet is dull on the Stage— The youthful Queen also at a second Representation was flat— Miss Tree spoke the Epilogue to As you like it, as a valedictory. Coll. and Mrs Towson were there— W. R. King— John and Nathl. Pope— Campbell came home with me at Midnight.
24. V:15 Sunday

Attended at St. John’s Church— Mr Hawley read the morning service for the 3d. Sunday after Trinity by mistake for the 2d. A Stranger preached from John 11.40. “Jesus saith unto her, said I not unto thee, that if thou wouldest believe, thou shouldest see the glory of God?” a well written, and affecting discourse upon that transcendently wonderful miracle; the raising of Lazarus from the dead.—of which event the preacher gave a narrative with commentary as he went along; dwelling emphatically upon the fact that it was performed at the petition of a woman— I spoke to President Van Buren, and asked half an hour’s conversation with him at 6. O’Clock this evening to which he acceded— Mrs Frye was here after morning church but would not stay— A. Campbell dined with us. After dinner heard Mr Hawley read prayers for the 2d. Sunday after Trinity, and preach from 1. Peter. 1.18. “For as much as ye know that ye were not redeemed with corruptible things, as silver and gold, from your vain conversation received by tradition from your fathers 19. But with the precious blood of Christ, as of a lamb without blemish and without spot.”— The atonement. Immediately after Church I went to the Presidents, and putting into his hand the Letter which I have received in duplicate from R. Rush, of 15. May requested him to read it— I then had a conversation of nearly two hours with him upon the Smithsonian bequest—referring to my report; and intreating him to have a plan prepared to recommend to Congress for the foundation of the Institution, at the commencement of the next Session of Congress.— I suggested to him the establishment of an Astronomical observatory—with a Salary for an Astronomer and Assistant—for nightly observations and periodical publication— Then annual courses of Lectures, upon the natural moral and political Sciences— And above all no jobbing— No Sinecures—No Monkish Stalls for lazy idlers— Mr Van Buren received all this with complacency, and apparent concurrence of opinion— Said he would look into my report— Wished me at leisure to name any persons who I thought might be usefully consulted— Appeared very favourably disposed to the Establishment of an Observatory, and willing to do right— I urged upon him the deep responsibility of the Nation to the world, and to all posterity worthily to fulfil the great object of the Testator— I only lament my inability to communicate half the solicitude, with which my heart is on this subject full; and the sluggishness with which I shall fail properly to pursue it. If I can but remember, to write upon it to L. Cass and T. Aspinwall—and to converse upon it with Edward Everett, and the Winthrop’s— Judge Nathaniel Pope paid us an evening visit— Dr Thomas was here to see Mary’s daughter Fanny whose health droops under the intense heat of the Season— Dr Huntt left the City last Wednesday, to seek relief and restoration if possible at the Virginia Sulphur Springs.
25. V. Monday

Committee of Manufactures— Present, Adams, Naylor, Slade. No Quorum— Memorial of Dr H. H. Sherwood, praying for leave to import Mathematical Instruments for the pursuit of his discoveries, duty free— Reading of the Journal— I claim the right to the floor when the Texas question comes up. Admitted by the Speaker— Petrikin moves a reconsideration of the Resolution to adjourn 9 July. Rule suspended. Previous Question Reconsideration refused 64 to 135— States called over for Resolutions, commencing with Maine— I moved a Call for Memucan Huntts newspaper the Report of the Committee of the House of Representatives of the State of Mississippi— As a call it must by the rule of the House lie over one day, and then, it is never in order to call it up. I asked the consideration of the motion now—refused 84 to 108— Recess. I answered a Letter from Jonathan Meredith of Baltimore— Evening Session— Sub-treasury Bill— Rhett’s ranting Speech in its favour—no reply— Enacting clause of the Bill struck out in Committee of the whole by tellers 92 to 86— Bill reported to the House with the enacting clause struck out— Previous Question immediately called and carried— Main question, not on concurring with the Committee of the whole in striking out the enacting clause, but on engrossing the Bill for a third reading— Call of the House pursued till 236 members answered to their names— Bill rejected by yeas and nays 111 to 125. Subdued shout from the galleries. H. A. Foster gives notice of a motion to reconsider— Walk home at 9. P.M.
26— V. Tuesday

H.R.U.S.— More than half an hour consumed upon preliminary questions. Robertson of Virginia intreated me to yield the floor for him to offer a Resolution, directing the Secretary of the Treasury to make special deposits of the public monies in certain State Banks, and to take as much Constitutional currency Gold and Silver for public revenue as he can get— I yielded the floor, but Petrikin objected, and said he would not let in at the window, what ought to come in at the doors. Robertson moved a suspension of the rules but was refused 70 to 123— I resumed my Speech on the annexation of Texas— Contested the reproach of Howard upon the Petitions of women; and on the Petitioners— I alluded to the votes of the South-Carolina members on Saturday, to suppress my Freedom of Speech, after their frequent declarations of their desire to discuss the Texas question. Pickens attempted an aukward self-justification, and said he was obliged to vote that I was out of order. Women Scripture. Antient History, Greece Athens, Aspasia—Sparta—Rome— Orders of the day. Foster moves reconsideration of the vote against the Sub-treasury Bill— F. Thomas opposes the reconsideration—which is rejected by yeas and nays 21 to 202. Bill to increase the army— Recess— Letter to Jonathan Meredith Baltimore— Evening Session. M’Kay— Gouverneur Kemble— Committee rise— Insupportable heat— Bills from the Senate read twice and referred— Committee rose once for want of a Quorum. Call of the House till a bare Quorum appeared— Adjourned at 7. Walk home— The family visited Mr T. B. Johnson— I take no part in the debate on the Bill to increase the army. Grennell is a member of the Military Committee and favours it— The majority of the Massachusetts delegation favour it— I do not.
27. IV. Wednesday

Call at the Pension Office with a Letter from S. A. Turner and a claim of a remnant of Pension for the son of a revolutionary soldier deceased.— H.R.U.S. I gave up the whole morning hour for the reception of Reports from Committees. They occupied two hours. I reported from the Committee of Manufactures Bill N. 854—for the remission of duties upon certain iron, imported for iron Steamboats, and obtained the assignment of one hour, next Saturday, immediately after the recess for the consideration of the 3. Senate Bills, and of the Bills reported by the Committee of Manufactures, now in Committee of the whole on the Union— Bill to increase the army debated till the recess and after till 1/2 past 7. Letters to Abbott Laurence, and George S. Hillard. I presented two Petitions for the Institution of a new Home Department. Referred to the Committee on Agriculture— A Resolution offered this day by Governor Lincoln from the Committee of Public buildings, was adopted for reversing again the arrangement of the Seats of the members and the Speaker’s Chair— Walk home— Mrs Thornton, Mrs Talbot and her daughter were here this Evening— And Dr Henry Perrine, whose exhibition of tropical plants, I have not yet been able to examine; but I promised to visit his committee room as soon as it may be in my power.
28. IV. Thursday.

Meeting of the Committee of Manufactures. Present Adams, Foster, Naylor, Tillinghast, Vail, Webster— Letter from the Secretary of the Treasury of 25. June 1838 and Report from the first Comptroller, relating to bleached and unbleached linens, and to certain equivocal articles of worsted. Naylor at his own request was authorised to report a bill, laying a duty of 2 cents per lb. on Starch— H.R.U.S. Morning hour on Texas— Women Petitioners. Howard not present— Johnson’s Life of Green— Ramsay’s History of the Revolution in South-Carolina— Deborah Gannett, and Morgan’s Report. Orders of the day. Bill to increase the army— Bell till the recess.— Letters to John Angier and Ragsdale— Session P.M. Skirmishing debate— Lincoln, Reed, Evans, Everett, Grennell, Harrison of Missouri—Yell— Many Amendments offered— Committee rise and report no Quorum. House refuse to adjourn— Rally a bare Quorum, and return into Comee. Amendment adopted— Bill reported to the House— Adjourn at 9. Heat insupportable Ride home. Thunder shower light— Fire in G. Street. Close to my houses. Miss Grandval went away suddenly this afternoon—to join her brother at the Island of Guadeloupe— She had been engaged by Mary to teach her children French. A Resolution was adopted this morning, at the motion of Rencher, instructing the Committee of Ways and Means to enquire into the expediency of authorizing a temporary investment of the Smithsonian legacy, as soon as it shall be received by the President of the United States— Fletcher of Vermont opposed the Bill for increasing the Army, for the purpose of keeping his Constituents in order; and the monthly pay of the private soldiers was at the motion of Cushman, of New-Hampshire increased from 7 to 8 dollars
